title: Financial help for families on Universal Credit this winter - and how to claim it
text:

Vulnerable families are shivering to save money instead of turning their heating on this winter, according to a survey.

Nearly three quarters admit to restricting their use of heating in their home over concerns about energy costs, a report by Moneyexpert found.

It comes as figures show the average household will spend £402.99 on energy bills - factoring in lighting, the forthcoming festive season, and seasonal household expenses such as repairs, insulation or redecoration, over the cold spell.

And those at risk financially are the most likely to suffer.

In the UK, around 2.3million currently claim Universal Credit - the six-in-one benefit designed to help support those who are struggling financially.

But what are your options if you cannot afford it? We've run through all of the extra ways you can save on Universal Credit below.

Cold Weather Payment

Cold Weather Payments are paid out by the Government during times of especially freezing weather.

The money goes to people on low incomes who receive a qualifying benefit, such as pension credit or certain employment benefits, when temperatures sink to below 0°C in the area they live in.

Payments are triggered by data collected by the Met Office from 94 weather stations around Britain.

The scheme runs each year from November 1 to March 31.

If you do qualify, you'll get a £25 a week payment for every seven-day spell of cold weather you experience.

The money is paid to the recipient within 14 days.

Find out more on Cold Weather Payments, here.

Free NHS prescriptions

Getting a prescription costs £9 a time, a cost people on Universal Credit struggling to make ends meet could struggle to meet.

It's cheaper if you buy in bulk, with a three month prescription pass costing £29.10 and an annual one £104 - but what if you didn't have to pay it at all?

It's well known that people under 16 or over 60 - as well women who are pregnant or new mums - don't have to pay, but it turns out quite a lot of people on benefits could qualify too.

You get free prescriptions if you're on Income Support, get income-based Jobseeker's Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance or Pension Credit Guarantee Credit.

Find out how to claim, here.

Warm Home Discount

(Image: Getty)

The Warm Home Discount is a support scheme aimed at households who may struggle to pay their energy bills.

The scheme was introduced by Government on April 1, 2011 and will run until 2021.

It's a one-off £140 discount on your energy bill over winter - but instead of being paid directly to you, it's automatically deducted from your bill over the winter months (between September and March).

You may also receive it as an energy rebate - all payments for last winter were paid by March 31, 2018. It's usually paid by Spring the following year, ie April 2020 for this coming winter.

Find out more on the Warm Home Discount, here.

Advance Payments

(Image: Getty)

The most common form of support offered to claimants while moving onto Universal Credit is an 'Advance Payment' – a loan valued at up to 100% of your first Universal Credit payment, paid back through deductions in your monthly payments as soon as they begin.

Claimants can choose the amount of Advance Payment they apply for, but they must be paid back within 12 months of the payment.

You can borrow up to 100% of your estimated payment to see you through the transitional period, but this will have to be paid back.

From October 2021, the Government plans to change the repayment period to 16 months, to improve affordability.

To get an advance payment, you can either speak to your work coach at the job centre or apply by calling the helpline on 0800 328 5644, Monday to Friday between 8am and 6pm.

Find out more on Universal Credit Advance Payments, here.

Hardship Payments

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

If you've been sanctioned - and your payments have been stopped as a result - you might qualify for a hardship payment.

Claimants can get around 60% of the amount they were sanctioned by in the last month to cover the costs of rent, heating, food or hygiene needs.

Like the advanced payment, you'll need to pay a hardship payment back through your Universal Credit payments.

To apply, contact the Universal Credit helpline on 0800 328 9344.

Find out more on Hardship Payments - and how to appeal sanctions, here.

Alternative Payment Arrangement

Your landlord might be able to apply for an alternative payment arrangement (APA) if you're falling behind on your rent.

The type of help you could get includes:

Getting your rent paid directly to your landlord.

Getting paid more frequently than once a month.

Receiving split payments, if you’re part of a couple.

You'll need to talk to your work coach at the JobCentre Plus to apply for an APA.

Budgeting Advance

A sudden or unexpected bill is enough to throw anyone's finances into chaos - and often accounts for why many people turn to rip-off payday lenders or illegal loan sharks for money in desperation.

However, if you're on a low income and receive certain benefits, you may be able to get a Budgeting Loan to tide you over until payday.

This is a type of loan offered by the Government and can help you pay for household items, clothes, rent in advance, maintenance, improvements or security for your home, travel, funeral costs and even loans taken out for any of the above.

You’re only eligible for a Budgeting Loan if you've been on certain benefits for six months - such as Income Support, income-based Jobseeker's Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance and Pension Credit.

If you've been switched onto Universal Credit from Pension Credit, any time spent claiming for it will count towards the six months.

However, you cannot get a Budgeting Loan if you've already been rolled onto Universal Credit (that's where advance payments come in), you’re involved in a strike or you already owe more than £1,500 in total for Crisis Loans and Budgeting Loans.

The lowest amount you can borrow is £100. However, this rises to £348 if you’re single, £464 if you have a partner and £812 if you or your partner claims Child Benefit.

How much you could get depends on whether you can pay the loan back, have savings of more than £1,000 (£2,000 if you or your partner are 63 or over) or are paying back an existing Budgeting Loan or Crisis Loan.

A Budgeting Loan is interest free so you only pay back what you borrow.

The repayments will be taken automatically from your benefits. The amounts you repay are based on how much benefit you get and what you can afford.

You normally have to repay the loan within 2 years (104 weeks).

Find out more on the Budgeting Loan, here.
